Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:

Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Greater appreciation for French literature and how very pretty the French language is :). Likewise, noticeable improvement in my French accent.
Built on french language skills in L2
Built upon the skills learned in L2 french, notably reading and listening skills. Review of grammar structures learned in earlier courses within the French department.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: very good continuation of L2 - lots of overlap in grammatical concepts, actually. Great readings and films.

Weaknesses: lectures could be more streamlined. For instance, more PowerPoints - I think there was only one slideshow per unit...

You really do improve your spoken french but the grammar moves very quickly. The assignments and audios sometimes did not line up and it was difficult to understand what the assignment was trying to teach me.

The class meets everyday and there are weekly quizzes. This makes it easier to retain grammar information and vocabulary over the course of the semester. There are a lot of exercises daily which also help reinforce what is learned.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: French classes work well online. Felt like I got to know my classmates + instructor rather well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes - if you got through L2, trust me, you're going to be just fine in L3. It reinforces more concepts than it introduces. And the readings and films are very good.
You have to take L3 so yes, but be warned it is alot of work and more difficult than L2.

If you're interested in taking French further I cannot recommend the Yale French sequence enough. Though it is a lot of hard work, there is a lot to be learned. Do keep in mind that you get out what you put into the class and in my experience there is a lot reading, and listening but less writing and speaking work in this class so you have to practice those outside of class.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
